content.text: Move the \(1.00 \text{N}\) load to a distance \(d = 25.0 \text{cm}\) from the \(0.0 \text{cm}\) end of the rule
Move one stand slightly, if necessary, so that the newton meters are as near to vertical as possible
Read, and record in Table 1.1, the value \(F_{\mathrm{p}}\) on newton meter P and the value \(F_{\mathrm{Q}}\) on newton meter Q
Repeat this procedure for \(d = 35.0 \text{cm}, d = 45.0 \text{cm}, d = 55.0 \text{cm}\) and \(d = 65.0 \text{cm}\)
Plot a graph of \(F_{\mathrm{p}} / \mathrm{N}\) (y-axis) against \(d / \mathrm{cm}\) (x-axis)
On the same axes, and using the same scales, plot a graph of \(F_{\mathrm{Q}} / \mathrm{N}\) (y-axis) against \(d / \mathrm{cm}\) (x-axis)
From your graph, determine \(F_0\), the value of \(F_{\mathrm{p}}\) where the two best-fit lines cross
Calculate the weight \(W_{\mathrm{R}}\) of the metre rule, using the equation \(W_{\mathrm{R}} = (2 \times F_{0}) - k\), where \(k = 1.00 \text{N}\)
WR =
This experiment can be done by moving a clamp to make the rule horizontal before taking each reading
Explain how to make sure that the rule is horizontal
You may draw a diagram

A student does the experiment with the same equipment as you. He reads values of \(F_{\mathrm{p}}\) which are the same as yours but his values of \(F_{\mathrm{Q}}\) are all higher than yours by 0.10 N
Suggest a reason for this difference. Assume that your values of \(F_{\mathrm{p}}\) and \(F_{\mathrm{Q}}\) in Table 1.1 are correct
In this experiment, you will investigate the forces supporting a metre rule
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 1.1
Do **not** attempt to change the position of either newton meter by adjusting the positions of the loops of thread attached to them
During this experiment, the thermometer must remain clamped securely to the stand
Pour \(150 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into the beaker
Place the thermometer in the water
Wait until the reading on the thermometer stops rising
In the first row of Table 2.1, record the temperature \(\theta\) of the water at \(t = 0\) and immediately start the stop-clock
Record the temperature \(\theta\) of the water at times \(t = 30 \text{s}\), \(t = 60 \text{s}\), \(t = 90 \text{s}\), \(t = 120 \text{s}\), \(t = 150 \text{s}\) and \(t = 180 \text{s}\)
Remove the thermometer from the beaker and tip out the water
Repeat (a) using \(50 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water
Complete the headings in Table 2.1

content.text: Write a conclusion stating how the volume of water affects the rate of cooling of the water. Justify your answer by reference to your results
Using your results for \(50 \text{cm}^3\) of water, calculate the average cooling rate \(x\) for the first \(90 \text{s}\) of the experiment. Use your readings from Table 2.1 and the equation
where \(T = 90 \text{s}\) and \(\theta_0\) and \(\theta_{90}\) are the temperatures at \(t = 0\) and \(t = 90 \text{s}\)
Include the unit for the cooling rate
A student does this experiment in a room with a much higher room temperature than your room
State how this affects her value of \(x\) in (d)(i)
Explain your answer by reference to your results from the beaker with \(50 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water
statement
explanation
Some thermal energy is lost from the sides of the beaker
Another student wishes to find out how much this loss of thermal energy affects the cooling rate of \(50 \text{cm}^3\) of water
Briefly describe an additional experiment that the student can carry out to investigate this. Explain how the results can be used to determine how much this loss affects the cooling rate
You are **not** required to carry out the experiment
additional experiment
use of results
In this experiment, you will investigate how the volume of water in a beaker affects the rate at which the water cools
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 2.1
Set the distance \(D\) between the mirror and the illuminated object to \(40 \text{cm}\)
Move the lens until a sharp image appears on the front of the card, by the side of the illuminated object
Measure the distance \(f_{1}\) between the lens and the illuminated object. This is a value for the focal length of the lens
Briefly describe a technique to obtain an image on the card that is as sharp as possible in this experiment
Arrange the illuminated object, lens and mirror as shown in Fig. 3.1
Measure \(h_{\mathrm{O}}\), the height of the illuminated triangle, as indicated in Fig. 3.2
Measure \(h_{\mathrm{I}}\), the height of the image of the triangle on the screen

parts.label: (ii)

content.text: Calculate a value \(W\) using the equation \(W = \frac{h_{\mathrm{O}}}{h_{\mathrm{I}}}\)
Calculate a second value \(f_{2}\) for the focal length of the lens, using the equation
\( f_{2} \)  = \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \quad (2)\]

content.text: Describe **one** difficulty that can be experienced when measuring the height of the image. Suggest an improvement to overcome this difficulty
difficulty
improvement
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 3.2
Set up the lens, illuminated object and screen as shown in Fig. 3.2
illuminated object
Set the distance between the illuminated object and the lens to \(u = 20.0 \text{cm}\)
Move the screen until a sharp image of the illuminated object appears on the screen
A student suggests that \(f_{1}\) and \(f_{2}\) should be equal
State whether your results support this suggestion
Justify your statement by reference to your results
statement
justification
Describe one precaution you took to obtain reliable measurements of \(f_{1}\) and \(u\) in this experiment
In this experiment, you will determine the focal length of a converging lens by different methods
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 3.1
A student investigates the resistance of a light-dependent resistor (LDR)
The resistance of an LDR changes as the intensity of light falling on it varies
The resistance \(R\) of the LDR is calculated using the equation \(R = \frac{V}{I}\)
where \(V\) is the potential difference (p.d.) across the LDR and \(I\) is the current in the LDR
Plan an experiment to investigate how the light intensity affects the resistance of an LDR. You are **not** required to carry out the experiment
The apparatus available includes:
an LDR
equipment to connect the circuit, part of which is shown in Fig. 4.1
a lamp with a power supply
In your plan, you should:
• complete the circuit diagram in Fig. 4.1 to show a voltmeter connected to measure the potential difference across the LDR
• state how the light intensity falling on the LDR will be varied and list any additional apparatus needed
• explain briefly how to do the experiment, including any precautions taken to ensure reliable results
• state **one** key variable to be kept constant
• draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to show how to display the readings (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table)
• explain how to use the readings to reach a conclusion
